results.title: Dutch Pirates Are Heroes
results.creator_credit: David E. Barrow, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “A World of Festivals”.
Every April, in the Dutch city of Brielle, the community holds a festival of dance, wine and song to commemorate the 1572 victory of Flemish pirates and beggars over the invading Spanish ships. The festival involves a procession through the main square and a re-creation of the battle between the pirates and the Spanish sailors.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David E. Barrow, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions

results.title: Ghost of the Spanish Warrior
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “A World of Festivals”.
The Moors and Christians festival of Alicoy in Alicante, Spain celebrates the defeat of the Moors by Christians after 500 years of occupation which left an indelible mark on Spanish culture and architecture. Led by a boy representing St. George, the town’s patron saint, groups of ‘crusaders’ stage a symbolic battle against the ‘moors’.

results.title: Yugoslavia's Mountain Homecoming
results.creator_credit: David E. Barrow, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “A World of Festivals”.
In the alpine area of Yugoslavia near Lake Bled the dairy farming peasants take their cattle to summer pastures high in the mountains where they live a frugal life. On their return in the autumn everyone turns out to greet them for festivities in which the cows are the guests of honour.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David E. Barrow, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions

results.title: The Venice Gondola Pageant
results.creator_credit: Barry Sloane, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “A World of Festivals”.
Once a year the gondoliers of Venice compete for the honour of being the fastest gondolier. This video looks at all of the pageantry which accompanies this event as well as touring Venice itself, describing a little of its history and crafts, including the construction of the gondolas themselves, and what it is like to live there.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barry Sloane, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions

results.title: A World of Festivals
results.creator_credit: Barry Sloane, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions
results.brief_description: A series which captures the appeal, colour and cultural tradition of European festivals and their locations. The rituals, forms of behaviour, dress, music, folklore and fun behind each event are explored, so that a fascinating and colourful picture of other societies’ culture and traditions is presented.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barry Sloane, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions

results.title: Belgium Salutes an Emperor
results.creator_credit: Barry Sloane, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “A World of Festivals”.
Homogon, one of the greatest festivals of the middle ages. In the 16th century it was staged by the people of Brussels to entertain an emperor and his royal court. Today it is recreated in perfect detail. Among the 1300 performers are a group of titled aristocrats of Belgium who play the parts of their ancestors.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barry Sloane, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions

results.title: Significance tests
results.creator_credit: Jill Singer, David Huntley, Peggy Girshman, COMAP and Chedd-Angier Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 20 of Series “Against all odds: inside statistics”.
Describes the basic reasoning behind tests of significance. The concept if a null hypothesis is explained, and it is shown how a z-test is carried out when the hypothesis concerns the mean of a normal population with known standard deviation. Hosted by Teresa Amabile.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jill Singer, David Huntley, Peggy Girshman, COMAP and Chedd-Angier Productions

results.title: Blocking and sampling
results.creator_credit: Jill Singer, Peggy Girshman, American Statistical Association, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Against all odds: inside statistics”.
When setting up an experiment one must consider if the subjects differ in any systematic way that may effect the results. Blocking is used when subjects share the same characteristics but when there may be some variability, as in agricultural experiments, such as the example shown, of testing new varieties of strawberries. A census counts everything but obviously has inherent difficulties which are illustrated. Sampling is a way of circumventing these difficulties and some of the problems of true representation are shown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jill Singer, Peggy Girshman, American Statistical Association, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP

results.title: Case study
results.creator_credit: Peggy Girshman, COMAP and Chedd-Angier Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 26 of Series “Against all odds: inside statistics”.
Hosted by Teresa Amabile, this program presents a detailed case study of statistics at work in a real world setting, demonstrating the range and power of concepts and techniques shown in the series. The case study follows the development and use of the drug AZT.

results.title: Correlation
results.creator_credit: Jill Singer, American Statistical Association, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Against all odds: inside statistics”.
This program looks at the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables, by interpreting correlations, deriving the correlation co-efficient, and correlation and regression. Examples used are the relationship between twins’ personality and whether they were raised together or apart, and the relationship between baseball home runs and players’ salaries.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jill Singer, American Statistical Association, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP
